The mean is 1 and the standard deviation is 0.

correctAnswer: The mean is 0 and the standard deviation is 1.

Which of the following best describes the Central Limit Theorem?
options: As the sample size increases, the sampling distribution of the mean approaches a normal distribution regardless of the population distribution.
The sample mean is always equal to the population mean.
The population distribution becomes normal as the sample size increases.
The standard deviation of the sample increases as sample size increases.
correctAnswer: As the sample size increases, the sampling distribution of the mean approaches a normal distribution regardless of the population distribution.

In a hypothesis test, the p-value represents:
options: The probability of obtaining a test statistic at least as extreme as the one observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
The probability that the null hypothesis is true.
The probability that the alternative hypothesis is true.
The probability of making a Type I error.
correctAnswer: The probability of obtaining a test statistic at least as extreme as the one observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true.

A 95% confidence interval for the population mean implies that:
options: If we were to take many samples and construct a confidence interval from each, 95% of those intervals would contain the true population mean.
There is a 95% probability that the true population mean lies within the specific interval calculated.
95% of the data values lie within the interval.
The sample mean is 95% likely to be correct.
correctAnswer: If we were to take many samples and construct a confidence interval from each, 95% of those intervals would contain the true population mean.
